fi.grimripper.loww.tiles

Class TileGrid<T extends Tile>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fi.grimripper.loww.tiles.TileGrid<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - type of tile in the grid
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FilledRowHexGrid, FilledSquareGrid

    public abstract class TileGrid<T extends Tile>
extends java.lang.Object
    Abstract base class for a grid of tiles that are of equal shape and size.
    Author:
    Marko Tuominen

    • Method Detail

      • getDirection

        public static Direction getDirection(Tile from,
                     Tile to)
        Determines the direction from one tile to another. If the two tiles are given in reversed order, then the resulting direction is the opposite. In case the tiles are same, returns null.
        Parameters:
        from - find direction from this tile to the other one
        to - find direction from the other tile to this one

      • getAngle

        public static double getAngle(Tile from,
              Tile to)
        Determines the angle from one tile to another. The angle is reminiscent of the unit circle: angles go from east (zero) to west (pi), positive angles to the north, and negative angles to the south. Angles to the main compass directions are:
        • north = pi/2
        • south = -pi/2
        • west = pi
        • east = 0
        Parameters:
        from - get angle from this tile to another
        to - get angle from another tile to this one
        Returns:
        the angle from the first tile to the second

      • intersects

                 Point p1,
                 Point p2)
        Determines if a line intersects the bounds of a tile.
        Parameters:
        tile - determine if the line intersects this tile's bounds
        p1 - the line's start point
        p2 - the line's end point
        Returns:
        the line intersects the tile
        See Also:
        intersects(Tile, double, double, double, double)

      • intersects

        public static boolean intersects(Tile tile,
                 double x1,
                 double y1,
                 double x2,
                 double y2)
        Determines if a line intersects the bounds of a tile. Doesn't check if one of the tile's edges is along the line. The given coordinates must specify a line. A point isn't considered to intersect anything, even if it lies on an edge of the tile. Also can't correctly handle a tile which has adjacent points with the same x and y coordinates (zero-length tile edge).
        Parameters:
        tile - determine if the line intersects this tile's bounds
        x1 - x-coordinate for the line's start point
        y1 - y-coordinate for the line's start point
        x2 - x-coordinate for the line's end point
        y2 - y-coordinate for the line's end point
        Returns:
        the line intersects the tile

      • getDirectPath

        public static <T extends Tile> T[] getDirectPath(TileGrid.LineHelper<T> helper,
                                 boolean hitEdge)
        Generates a path between two tiles, going neighbor to neighbor. The path is as straight as possible in the tile grid. A path from a tile to itself is an array with only the single tile. Otherwise, there's at least two tiles (when the path's ends are neighbors).

        The path can also progress through the target tile and straight ahead until the tile grid's edge. In this case, the second parameter doesn't determine the path's end, but only the path's direction. The last tile in the path is the one farthest away from the starting tile among the tiles that intersect the direct line.

        At each step, there are at most two alternatives for progress. The better one is selected, unless they're equal. In that case, they're both added to the path. The path effectively widens to two tiles for a step.

        Parameters:
        helper - a line helper with data about the direct line and tiles along it
        hitEdge - true to create a path all the way to a tile grid edge
        Returns:
        the straightest possible tile path to the specified destination, or to a tile grid edge in the specified direction

      • hasLineOfSight

        public static boolean hasLineOfSight(TileGrid.LineHelper<?> helper,
                     Obstacle losFor)
        Finds out whether or not there's a line of sight between two tiles. Line of sight is determined for an obstacle, using its total height with occupy height, to a tile, using its terrain height.
        Parameters:
        helper - a line helper with data for the direct line and tiles along the line
        losFor - check line of sight for this obstacle
        Returns:
        there are no obstacles blocking line of sight
        See Also:
        hasLineOfSight(LineHelper, Obstacle, Obstacle)

      • hasLineOfSight

        public static <T extends Tile> boolean hasLineOfSight(TileGrid.LineHelper<T> helper,
                                      Obstacle losFor,
                                      Obstacle losTo)
        Finds out whether or not there's a line of sight for an obstacle to another obstacle. Line of sight is along the most direct path between two tiles. Obstacles on that line can affect line of sight. If any obstacle blocks visibility, then there's no line of sight. The obstacle for which the line of sight is generated may influence the outcome, because obstacles can be biased about which other obstacles' line of sight they block. In addition to whether an obstacle blocks line of sight, its height determines if it's possible for it to block the line of sight. It is possible to see over obstacles that are low enough, even if those obstacles are opaque.

        The seven height categories deep, shallow, flat, low, high, very high and blocking are used for height comparisons. An obstacle whose height is blocking can always block line of sight, and there's no viewing over it. Otherwise, the generic check of what is looked over uses the ratio of obstacle's height above lower of viewer and target height and the difference between target and viewer height in comparison to distance between the lower of viewer and target and the obstacle. If the height ratio is equal to or less than the distance normalized by full distance between viewer and target, it's possible to see over the obstacle.

        From the generic check, if an obstacle is lower than either the viewer or the target, and at most as high as the other of them, it can always be looked over. The height ratio is at most zero. Likewise, if an obstacle's height is the same as the higher of viewer and target height, it can't be looked over because height ratio is at least one.

        The direct line is determined by a line helper. Since a helper can't be reset, a new one should be used. Otherwise behavior is undefined. The viewer obstacle doesn't actually need to reside in the helper's starting tile, but it needs to be placed so that its occupy height can be used. The same applies to the target obstacle and the helper's target tile. Both of these obstacles are ignored along the line, in case they cover multiple tiles. An obstacle can't block its own line of sight, or another's line of sight to itself. The line helper's starting and target tiles don't affect the line of sight.

        Parameters:
        helper - a line helper with data for direct line and tiles along the line
        losFor - check line of sight for this obstacle
        losTo - check line of sight to this obstacle (if null, terrain height in the helper's target tile is used instead)
        Returns:
        there are no obstacles blocking line of sight

      • getTileAtXY

        public abstract T getTileAtXY(double x,
            double y)
        Gets a tile at a specific location by x- and y-coordinates. There can be some inaccuracy regarding the coordinates of a tile. An implementation can then select a tile as is most convenient. The coordinates can also be outside the grid, or a tile location can be empty. Then null is returned. Negative values can also be allowed, depending on implementation.
        Parameters:
        x - the tile's x-coordinate
        y - the tile's y-coordinate
        Returns:
        tile at the given location (can be null)

      • getTileAtRC

        public abstract T getTileAtRC(int row,
            int col)
        Gets a tile at a specific location by row and column. The meaning of rows and columns can vary depending on the tile grid's implementation, but any coordinates will correspond to a specific tile. The coordinates can be outside the grid, or a tile location can be empty. Then null is returned. Negative values can also be allowed, depending on implementation.
        Parameters:
        row - the tile's row
        col - the tile's column
        Returns:
        tile at the given location (can be null)

      • getTileAtPoint

        public T getTileAtPoint(Point point)
        Gets a tile at a specific point.
        Parameters:
        point - a point inside the tile
        Returns:
        tile at the point (can be null)
        See Also:
        getTileAtXY(double, double)
